noun.description: The arrangement or disposition of people or things in relation to each other according to a particular sequence, pattern, or method.
examples: I filed the cards in alphabetical order

noun.description: An authoritative command, direction, or instruction.
examples: he was not going to take orders from a mere administrator
the skipper gave the order to abandon ship

noun.description: A particular social, political, or economic system.
examples: if only the peasantry would rise up against the established order

noun.description: A society of monks, priests, nuns, etc., living according to certain religious and social regulations and discipline and at least some of whose members take solemn vows.
The quality, nature, or importance of something.
examples: with musical talent of this order, von Karajan would have been a phenomenon in any age

noun.description: A principal taxonomic category that ranks below class and above family.
Any of the five classical styles of architecture (Doric, Ionic, Corinthian, Tuscan, and Composite) based on the proportions of columns, amount of decoration, etc.
Equipment or uniform for a specified purpose or of a specified type.
The degree of complexity of an equation, expression, etc., as denoted by an ordinal number.

verb.description: Give an authoritative direction or instruction to do something.
examples: the court ordered that the case should be heard at the end of August
her father ordered her back home

verb.description: Request (something) to be made, supplied, or served.
examples: my friend ordered the tickets last week
I asked the security guard to order me a taxi
are you ready to order, sir?

verb.description: Arrange (something) in a methodical or appropriate way.
examples: all entries are ordered by date

phrases: But on top of that, you have to put the chronology in order here.
Keep the cheques in order, and cash them in order, and don't forget to tick each one off your list each night you get back to the hotel.
Every item needed to be kept, in order, between the correct allocated colour coded dividers.
Aaron scrambled to pick up the papers and put them in order.
The history portion isn't always in order, which can be a bit confusing.
origin: Middle English: from Old French ordre, from Latin ordo, ordin- row, series, rank.
